title-group.article-title: A parametric study and performance investigation of thermoelectric refrigeration system using computational fluid dynamics

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: Global commercial market forecasted around 45 billion US dollars for refrigeration equipment in 2021. Currently used refrigerants have high global warming potential (GWP); hence, environment-friendly refrigeration system using the Peltier effect is being considered for this research. The thermodynamic refrigeration system has a low coefficient of performance (COP), when compared to chlorofluorocarbon (CFC) and hydrofluorocarbon (HCFC) refrigeration systems. The design of various models of the thermoelectric refrigerator (TER) is created using ANSYS workbench. Each new design is analysed with computational fluid dynamics (CFD) analysis tool by altering insulating materials such as nickel with aluminium foil and polyurethane foam in airflow streamline of thermoelectric refrigeration. Temperature differences obtained between 7.5 and 9.4 °C are tabulated after each run using the finite volume method. Optimization of inner design and insulation material is done by using computational fluid dynamics analysis in the ANSYS FLUENT software. The results of sharp edge design have proved better when compared to partially round edge design and fillet design, 7.85 °C for the cold region and 54.85 °C for the hot region. Further research is expected using the multistage Peltier module and smart temperature control unit to improve the COP of the TER system.

custom-meta.meta-value: The Society of Refrigeration and Air Conditioning Engineers of Korea
Engineering Thermodynamics, Heat and Mass Transfer

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Climate change is a serious problem which is affecting the world currently. The global warming index gives the potential of a substance to cause global warming. Traditionally used refrigerants such as hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFCs) and chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) have global warming index of 300 and 400, respectively. It can be controlled by making necessary changes in our current industrial practices. One such change is the usage of a thermoelectric refrigeration system using the Peltier module. The Peltier module is flameless and odourless and made with eco-friendly materials. Since the Peltier module has the lowest global warming potential near unity, it is the preferred alternative solution when considered from the environmental point of view. Yet, thermodynamically, the Peltier module refrigeration system has a low coefficient of performance when compared to HCFC and CFC refrigeration systems.

The researchers have identified a wide scope for the Peltier effect, in the refrigeration field. Thermoelectric refrigerator (TER) works on the principle of the Peltier effect. In refrigerators, the Peltier effect can be achieved by merely passing a small current through a close circuit made up of two dissimilar materials without using any moving parts. The TER consist of several thermos electric light sandwiched between two thermally conductive plates, one cold and one hot. TER cannot compete with vapour compression refrigeration systems because of their low coefficient of performance (COP).

Thermoelectric cooler (TEC) uses the Peltier effect to create a heat flux at the junction of two different types of materials. Materials must have a combination of low thermal conductivity and high electric conductivity. Common thermos electric materials used in semiconductors include bismuth telluride, lead telluride, silicon–germanium, and bismuth antimonide alloys.

sec.title: Literature review
sec.p: A survey of work by researchers in the field of thermoelectric refrigeration is discussed here.

Schoenfeld [1] proposed that there are two research areas to increase the TEC performance; first is material research on thermoelectric semiconductors, and the other is in system-level assembly where heat dissipation techniques are considered for the Peltier module. The most common thermoelectric semiconductor in today’s TECs is bismuth telluride (Bi2Te3), which leads to an increase in the optimum COP.

Benziger et al. [2] state that the present air conditioner model that produces cooling impact by refrigerants like Freon, ammonia, and so forth utilizing these refrigerants can get the most extreme resulting in one main disadvantage that is harmful gas emission and heating. These problems can be prevented by using a thermoelectric module. This paper focused on the experimentation of thermoelectric air conditioner using different modules.

Jagan Mohan Reddy [3] proposed a low-force, eco-accommodating multipurpose thermoelectric cooler to improve the performance of the Peltier model TER. The productivity of the refrigerator has been examined with multi-purpose functionality and cost adequacy of the module. It was subsequently upgraded for utilization in hostels, electronics, and medical and food industries.
Huang et al. [4] studied the impact of the heat sink and thermal resistance on the cooling module and also tested its ideal performance.

Chang et al. [5] studied the impact of current input and the heat is compared with the ideal current flow for the module. The thermoelectric modules were found to be more practical at lower heat loads.

Cosnier et al. [6] introduced a test and insightful investigation study on a thermoelectric framework for pre-cooling and pre-warming and discovered the system with a better coefficient of performance (COP) of 1.5 for the cooling mode and around 2 for the heating mode. In this case, the results were not attained in the experimental work because of inconsistent utilization of the heat sink.

Dai et al. [7] designed a thermoelectric cooler, driven by solar-oriented PV cells to serve individuals stationed in provincial territories. This system was tested under different radiation intensities, and they found that the framework execution was dominated by the available power of radiation. The cooler temperature was in the range of 5 and 10 °C, and COP was 0.3.

Abdul Wahab et al. [8] designed a portable solar thermoelectric refrigerator. The results presented in the work signify that the refrigerator can attain a minimum temperature of 5 °C with a COP of 0.16. It stated that the efficiency of the thermoelectric refrigerators is still lower than its compressor counterpart. Some improvements were proposed to increase the COP, such as improving the thermal interfaces between the modules and the heat sinks as well as decreasing the thermal resistance of the sinks.

Chingwa et al. [9] planned to develop an independent electrical force source design and power conditioning unit to guarantee a steady and consistent voltage supply to meet TEC refrigerator requirements.

Riff et al. [10] examined the TE air condition systems made with air- and water-cooled heat sink. A tube heat sink was planned with the enhancement of the inside balanced fin length and pitch. The barrel-shaped design was fit for decreasing heat exchanger volume and thermal obstruction. An evaporative water “condenser” was suggested for the outdoor unit, which would cool the circulated water, close to the wet-bulb temperature through convective and evaporative cooling.

Pietrzyk et al. [11] designed TER using the B-factor as the solitary portrayal factor. The electrical contact resistance did not influence the power utilization of the module, as long as the B-factor was kept consistent.

Ahmad et al. [12] state that the thermoelectric air chiller deploys solid-state cooling, so its efficiency is less than the actual refrigeration system cycle. Its applications are limited because of less refrigeration space, and as such, it is used for electronic cooling of laboratory equipments. Researchers are working on reducing the irreversibility of the system and increasing the COP of TEC.

Patil et al. [13] accomplished better COP and temperature control to consolidate TER with other cooling systems. For instance, joining VCR and TER systems decreases energy utilization and gives high COP and substantial temperature control inside the refrigerated zone. Subsequently, it is smarter to have such hybrid systems and gadgets which decrease absolute energy utilization.

Rokde et al. [14] state that the solar-based Peltier refrigerator utilized in this analysis is cost-proficient, the most important factor of the present time. By controlling the temperature of the cooling unit, it can be utilized in different sectors like in the rural areas where dairy items need consideration. In clinical areas for discarding blood and pharmaceuticals, the performance of the refrigerator can be increased by increasing the quantity of the Peltier plate module which is also called a multistage Peltier module that eventually diminishes the temperature in less time.

Bolaji [15] proposed that vapour fume compression refrigeration system is the most broadly utilized technique throughout the world. The advantages and disadvantages of these refrigerants were discussed so that researchers can focus on the weaknesses and make them satisfactory for the world customers.
Dhokane et al. [16] considered that adsorption can be a choice to reduce CO2 emissions and electricity demand when they are driven by solar energy.

Smrithi et al. [17] state that the cooling system was analysed using a Peltier module and fuelled by solar energy. The prototype can be adjusted according to specific requirements by changing the Peltier component by a series–parallel combination to accomplish a greater degree of temperature variations.

Rawat et al. [18] state that the audit on novel TER and space model conditioning confirms temperature decrease of 11 °C without any heat load and 9 °C with 100 ml of water in a refrigeration space at 23 °C. The determined COP of the test thermoelectric refrigeration cabinet was 0.1. The thermoelectric cooling systems with renewable energy made them more suitable for the present environment conditions.

Chaudhary et al. [19] utilized solar energy for its operation. Solar refrigerator using the Peltier module does not require any kind of refrigerant and mechanical device like compressor prime mover etc. Consequently, there are a few unique different ways to cool gadgets to eliminate the heat from the industrial-fenced area as well as the clinical enclosure. Thermoelectric cooling is arising as a genuinely significant method that can be considered in the treatment of medium applications.

Patel et al. [20] examined the single-stage and multistage TEC air cooling modules. It was very simple to accomplish the huge temperature contrast in the single-stage TE module. However, the COP of the single-stage module was extremely less for home use. The authors described the study for heat transfer through a thermos electric cooler by using a multistage TE module.
Durgakar et al. [21] proposed that the solar energy-oriented refrigeration system of 12 V DC boxes reduces the inner temperature of TER more than the ambient temperature.

Sujith et al. [22] successfully designed a refrigeration system which fulfils the goal of the thermoelectric refrigeration system. Limitations of the system were identified which used light heat load to lower the temperature. These coolers can only be utilized where there is no power supply.

Liao et al. [23] proposed a three-dimensional TEG model comprising 127 pairs of thermocouples. Temperature subordinate material properties were considered for the finite element model, and experimentation on the TEG system was modelled. The results were found to be in good acceptable concurrence with the exploratory experimental data, and the most extreme deviation was below 6% which demonstrated the exactness of the mathematical model.

Varma [24] stated even though the present technologies look very eco-friendly like mechanical refrigeration systems, the improvization efforts should consistently be checked from the ecological point of view before they are executed.

Enescu et al. [25] proposed thermoelectric cooling has proven better applications for household operations. Comparative studies with varying materials and designs are done to increase the performance of TER.

Saleh et al. [26] proposed streamlining of the activity between the compressor speed factor and pressure depletion on various sides of the Joule–Thomson valve is important. In the refrigeration cycle, the power of electricity and the steam needed in the compressor should be added inside the unit itself. The refrigeration cycles are appropriate for deserts and dry territories and play a significant part in saving asset like drinking water.

Jugsujinda et al. [27] proposed that TEC cold plate temperature inside TER utilized an electric current of 3.5 A. The temperature variation of 30 to − 4.2 °C within an hour was noted and attempted to keep it constant at − 7.4 °C for 24 h. TER was diminished from 30 to 20 °C for an hour, followed by diminishing temperature over 24 h. The max COP of TEC and TER was determined to be 3.0 and 0.65, respectively.

Satheeshkumar Palaniappan et al. [28] carried an investigation on the conduct of the thermoelectric refrigeration system by utilizing the ANSYS software. Bi-Te and Pb-Te were considered as semiconducting materials for the examination. The COP of the thermoelectric refrigeration system decreases with an expansion in the temperature distinction. The COP of the Bi-Te system was 13.46% higher than that of the Pb-Te system, under similar working conditions.

He et al. [29] proposed that the working voltage and current of the semiconductor are significant for improving the COP of the refrigeration box. A too-high temperature from the hot side will influence the working presentation of the refrigeration box, by hypothetical prediction which was different from the experimental esteem value. The choice of insulation material assumes a significant role in the thermoelectric refrigeration box.

Francis et al. [30] proposed a thermoelectric refrigerator by keeping the temperature constant at 4 °C within an enclosed wall. The average estimated values of the parameters of bismuth telluride (Bi2-Te3) are used for examination.

Kasaeian et al. [31] review the experiential and theoretical studies carried out with environmentally friendly refrigerants such as hydrocarbons, hydrofluorocarbons, R744 (carbon dioxide), hydrofluoroolefin, and nanorefrigerants. It was seen that few defects in the deformities in the R744 system were identified to their low idle heat.

Goldsmid [32] proposed that bismuth telluride and its alloys have widely used materials for thermoelectric refrigeration. The authors suggested these are the best materials for use in thermoelectric generators when the temperature of the heat source is moderate.

Tijani et al. [33] proposed solar-oriented, fuelled multistage thermoelectric cooling framework for tackling the perpetual issue of home-grown heated water transcendent during the summer season. The framework effectively evolved and was assessed progressively for cooling water for temperature above the surrounding condition.
Zhang et al. [34] used a reversible conversion model between heat and electricity without emission.

Shankar et al. [35] stated that the performance analysis accompanied with R438a (Freon M099), R407C (Freon 407C), R410 (Freon 410C), and R454C (Opteon Xl20) were found to be environment-friendly alternatives for R22. It was concluded that among the alternatives, condensation temperatures of 20 °C for R454c and 30 °C for R407c were most suitable for TER. These choices have amazingly low ozone depletion potential (ODP) and less global warming potential (GWP). Hence, it was proposed that the above alternatives are highly considerable from both performance and environmental point of view.

sec.title: Aims
sec.p: The literature review is evident that the Peltier module has vital trademark and utilization in refrigeration framework rather than refrigerants. In ordinary fridges, pivoting parts like blower, development valve, coolants and so forth are included which prompts vibrations and commotion. Even though coolant is not eco-friendly and costlier, still, there are various provincial domains where people need to oversee issues like power, GWP, and ODP.

Our principal aims are as follows:
Development of a computational calculation model that simulates thermoelectric refrigerators
Experimental validation of the computational model by building a thermoelectric refrigerator

The secondary aim is as follows:
Design an environmental-friendly refrigeration system that works on the principle of the Peltier effect to replace the refrigerants used in conventional refrigerators. As a pre-requisite, the TER system is designed and analysed using the ANSYS FLUENT CFD software.

sec.title: Computational model
sec.p:
Conceptual design is a fluid process. New ideas and problems are considered as a part of the design and investigated in ever-increasing details. Each time a component is changed, the latest design is analysed on the new insulation material [38]. The choice of materials depends on the following factors:
Strength-to-weight ratio
Availability and cost
Ease of fabrication
Wear resistance

The initial consideration for the fabrication material includes an aluminium composite panel (silver) and transparent glass fibre for the cooling side. The final selection of the material was done based on the changes in performance and efficiency. Figure 1 shows the flowchart of the methodology, and Fig. 2 shows the prototype TEL module 12,715.Fig. 2
Porotype TEC module 12,715

sec.title: Experimental method
sec.p:
In the experiment, Tech-12715 thermoelectric model is used, consisting of 127 semiconductors and 19% cooling rate in the time span of 25 min compared to other models, and the specification is listed in Table 1. The warmth sink utilized for the examination is a Hyper H410R elite air cooler that is fit for a small structure with 4 warmth pipes. The heat sink configuration is listed in Table 2. The overall dimensions of the refrigerator are listed in Table 3.Table 1

Simulation is performed on those areas where there is no stress and airflow. While performing the analysis, the material property will be assigned based on the material density, volume of the component, and the weight of the material. Basically, the refrigeration box is made of an aluminium composite panel on the left side of the box and glass fibre on the right side of the box. The inner section of the refrigeration box has two partitions for different temperatures in this section. The placement of the Peltier module is done right in the centre of the partition which takes 100 mm of the area in the middle section. The external structure of the design is kept constant, and only the internal structure of the design is optimized. There are three different designs made in order to get a suitable design for improving the performance. Polyurethane and aluminium composite panel were used for better insulation in this model. The sharp edges of the design were changed to partially rounded corners to get a turbulent air flow which may give increase the efficiency and performance of the thermoelectric refrigerator. The materials used for this design are still the same as the previous design. In the design of fully round edges, the fillet radius is more than the previous design in order to get a smoother flow of air in the insulated area on the hot side and cooling side of the refrigerator [39]. Properties of thermoelectric materials, like the Seebeck coefficient (α), electrical resistivity (ρ), and warm conductivity (k), are essential for the module’s presentation. These properties can be consolidated for thermoelectric modules, which can be expanded to improve module execution. Two assumptions are made before designing these models [40].
The temperature of the hot side and cold side of the module is not affected by the input current.
No heat is gained from the environment on the cold side of the TER.

sec.title: Simulation method
sec.p: A simulation methodology has been examined on a thermoelectric cooler considering the same parameters used in the experimental study. After the computations were completed, the results are compared with experimental data.

The analysis of the 3D mesh domain image of the thermoelectric cooler is shown in Fig. 3.Fig. 3
General view of mesh case

This mesh contains about 170,000 cells, size is 2 × 10−4, maximum element growth rate is 1.3, curvature factor is 0.2, and resolution at narrow regions is 1. The geometry and the mesh are created using the computational fluid dynamics software.

The thermal analysis performed on the designed thermoelectric refrigerator was based on the results obtained after optimization of internal design considering the thermal stress and heat flux, in the compartments of the Peltier module. The analysis is conducted using the ANSYS workbench 19.2 and CFD software. The meshed model is exported to the ANSYS FLUENT software for further analysis. Pressure-based and steady-time state solver is used within an absolute velocity range. Simulation with domain extents of x minimum from − 0.25 m to x maximum 0.25 m and y minimum from − 0.35 m to y maximum 0.35 m. The pseudo-transient is used as a boundary condition as it has the ability to change temperature with respect to the time of convergence [41, 42]. It is done with the initialization of temperature input, i.e. 333 °K. for the simulations of the k-epsilon model. The model is considered with standard wall functions of C-2 epsilon of 1.9, TKE Prandtl number of 1, TDR Prandtl number of 1.2 and wall Prandtl number of 0.85, flow current number 200 with explicit relocation factors such as momentum and pressure of 0.5, under relocation factors such as density of 1, body forces 1, turbulent kinetic energy 0.8, and turbulent dissipation rate of 0.8. The surface temperature for T = 25 °C is shown in Fig. 4.Fig. 4
Surface temperature for T = 25 °C

The convergence plots for boundary conditions should be the first starting point to check the convergence of the simulation. The plots enable us to understand global and local imbalances in CFT simulation. The iteration number considered is a large value of 10,000, if it satisfies the boundary condition. Convergence is achieved when the grid is sufficiently fine in a high-gradient region, and relaxation parameters are not too low (in segregated solver—Courant number in coupled solver). The reporting interval sets the number of iterations that will pass before convergence monitors are printed. The default value is 1.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
The solution obtained is considered for the thermal analysis in the FEA platform. The temperature distribution and heat flux values are tabulated in Table 4 and compared for improvization in the performance of TER [43]. Figure 5a shows that the temperature distribution of TER without a fillet model has the maximum temperature of the cold side that reaches up to 6.441 to 2.7292 °C, and on the hot side, it is between 10.153 and 6.441 °C. Figure 5b shows that the mode of heat transfer is convection. The maximum heat flux obtained is 0.3335 W/mm2 and min 0.083376 W/mm2. It indicates that the cold side and hot side compartment variation is between 0.083376 W/mm2. Figure 6a shows the temperature distribution of TER with the fillet model: the cold left side compartment indicates min of 6.3333 to 4 °C, and the hot right compartment indicates 13.333 to 11 °C. Figure 6b shows the max and min modes of heat transfer of convection: a maximum heat flux of 0.3335 W/mm2 for the top and bottom sides of the TER and a min. of 0.0833 w/mm2 for the rest of the box. The minimum temperature achieved without fillet is up to 2.7 °C. The model with a fillet is shown with the better dissipation of heat around the hot side of the model with a max. of 12.7 °C achieved.Table 4

CFD analysis was performed on all proposed models of TER with reference to temperature distribution, velocity, and streamline properties, and the results were recorded. Figure 7 shows the temperature distribution of the TER model with sharp edges: a temperature of 4.85 °C is attained on the cold side, and the max. heat produced on the hot side is 50 °C. Figure 8 shows the temperature distribution between the TER refrigerator with a partially rounded design recorded a minimum temperature of 7.85 °C and a max. of 54.85 °C. Figure 9 shows the temperature distribution of the TEC refrigerator with a fully rounded design attaining a minimum temperature of 6.85 °C with a max temperature on the hot side of the model of 52.85 °C. The temperature distribution of the designed models is tabulated in Table 5. In the comparison of temperature distribution on the cold side of the TER model concerning design and insulation materials, a min. temperature of 5 °C is achieved on the cold side of the model with sharp edges and insulation material of polyurethane foam [44]. On the hot side of the TER model concerning insulation material and varying designs, it reached a max. temperature of 54.85 °C.Fig. 7

The velocity distribution from CFD analysis is as follows: Fig. 10 shows the velocity distribution of the TER model with sharp edges for two different insulation materials, velocity achieved in the cold side of polyurethane material is 4.399 m/s and on the hot side is 0.011 m/s. The velocity distribution of the TER model with partially round edges is as shown in Fig. 11. Due to the change in internal chamber design, the velocity distribution shows a gradual change in the distribution with 5.013 m/s on the cold side and 0.016 m/s on the hot side. Figure 12 shows the velocity distribution for two different TER models with different insulation materials for fully rounded edges, drastic change in velocity is inferred with 5.42 m/s in the cold region and 0.0073 m/s in the hot region of the model. Velocity distribution comparison, inferred with a fully rounded design of TER showing higher velocity distribution with min. 4.399 m/s and max. of 5.42 m/s in a cold region of model, is tabulated in Table 6. Velocity distribution graph on the hot region of TER, change in velocity due to modified internal design, is observed in the hot region of model with a min. of 0.011 m/s and a max. of 0.073 m/s.Fig. 10

Streamline distribution of the designed model with insulation material is listed in Table 7. The streamline distribution of the TER model with sharp edges is shown in Fig. 13 with 4.014 m/s achieved in the cold region of the model and 0.010 m/s in the hot region. Figure 14 shows the streamline distribution of the partially round TER model with two different insulation materials, nickel with aluminium foil material on the cold region showing 4.677 m/s and the hot region with 0.064 m/s, whereas polyurethane foam material gives 4.385 m/s on the cold side and 0.072 m/s on the hot side. Figure 15 shows the streamlines in TER models with fully rounded corners, polyurethane gives 4.700 m/s in the cold region and 0.068 m/s on the hot side. The gradual change in streamlines can be observed due to changes in design [45].Table 7

Table 8 shows the COP of the TER models resulting in a change in performance in a fully round edges model with 0.56 performance compared to other models. Hence, changes in internal insulation design play an important role in the increase in COP of a thermoelectric refrigeration system.Table 8
COP of different Peltier designs

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this study on thermoelectric refrigerator, the temperature distribution in the FEA model without fillet has a minimum temperature in the cold region of the model of 2.77 °C and 10.15 °C in the hot region with a temperature difference of 7 °C whereas the with fillet model has the temperature of 4 °C in the cold region and 13.4 °C in the hot region with the temperature difference of 9.4 °C showing FEA model with fillet has better performance due to higher temperature difference and fillet design. The temperature distribution in CFD analysis models with sharp edges and partially rounded corner models have higher performance change comparatively to fully round design, due to the high temperature difference and increased volume in the cold region with 7.85 °C in the cold region and 80 °C in the hot region resulting in the gradual increase of COP from 0.56 to 0.54. Temperature distribution in the CFD model with partially round edges is observed to have increased temperature difference by 22.5 °C due to changes in design and insulation material on the inner surfaces of the model.

Velocity distribution in the CFD model with partially round edges has observed that it has gradually high pressure comparatively of 5.031 m/s in the cold region and 0.016 m/s in the hot region. Streamline distribution in a partly rounded CFD model with polyurethane foam as insulation material has been observed that is comparatively exceptional with streamlines of 4.385 m/s in the cold region and 0.072 m/s in the hot region of the model. The performance of the TER model is higher in sharp edges and partially rounded models with insulation material of polyurethane foam on both regions compared to nickel with aluminium foil.

It is evident that from the results in order to have a better effect on the performance of the Peltier effect, one has to modify the inner design with balanced insulation material. Since the FEA and CFD analysis is done in standard values of the Peltier module, it is better to maintain and control the temperatures to have sustainability. The data obtained from the analyses have been compared with the experimental results and found to agree with each other.

sec.title: Future scope
sec.p:
The study was concentrated on comparing various thermal and aerodynamic characteristics on inner surface designs, by performing FEA and CFD analysis; however, the study may be extended in the following areas:
Design optimization based on volume of cooling region with an extra chamber for insulation and air vents for dissipation of heat.
Multistage Peltier module can be used in order to obtain spontaneous cooling and increase in performance.
